RAPPLER.article_headline: DOH expands 2nd COVID-19 booster shot to adults aged 50 and up
RAPPLER.article_body: MANILA, Philippines – The Department of Health (DOH) has allowed adults aged 50 and above, and those with comorbidities, aged 18 to 49, to get their second COVID-19 booster shot. In a statement on Tuesday, July 26, the DOH said that the move is based on the recommendations of the Health Technology Assessment Council to the agency. It added that only Pfizer and Moderna vaccines will be used for them, and will be given fourth months after their first booster or third dose of the vaccine. “As vaccine immunity wanes over time, we are dedicated to helping our people remain protected against COVID-19. We are making it easier for as many of our people to avail of the primary series and boosters – including second boosters,” DOH officer-in-charge Maria Rosario Vergeire said. The DOH said that eligible individuals can check the schedule of vaccine deployment with their local government units and private service providers. “As part of the preparation for the administration of second booster doses to the above-mentioned populations, orientations for local government units and vaccination centers are already scheduled,” the DOH said. Prior to this development, the second booster shot was only limited to healthcare workers, senior citizens, and immunocompromised individuals with specific medical conditions. The DOH said that eligible individuals need to bring their vaccination card and a valid ID. “A medical certificate is not required, even for those with comorbidities. The medical screener or doctor at the vaccination site is authorized to assess and make the determination,” the agency added. The DOH decided to administer a second booster shot to the age groups as the country deals with a new surge in cases driven by Omicron offshoots. “The DOH, along with other government agencies and private sector partners, aims to increase vaccine coverage nationwide. We need every eligible Juan and Juana to turn this into a whole-of-society fight against the virus,” Vergeire said. The government is targeting to administer booster shots to 50% of the eligible fully vaccinated individuals during the first 100 days of the administration of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., or to 23 million people. As of July 21, some 71 million individuals have been fully vaccinated. Only 15 million have availed of the first booster, while some 1.1 million have availed of their second booster. – Rappler.com

RAPPLER.article_headline: MT Princess Empress oil cargo spills, threatens marine protected areas
RAPPLER.article_body: BATANGAS, Philippines – Oil sludge from the capsized MT Princess Empress has reached the shores of Pola and Pinamalayan in Oriental Mindoro, the Philippine Coast Guard (PCG) Southern Tagalog said on Thursday, March 2. Even worse though, the vessel’s industrial oil cargo has also started to leak into waters off Naujan town, Mindoro Oriental, the PCG said. The announcement raised fears among fisher groups and environmentalists of long-term damage to the lush maritime environment around Mindoro island. The Department of Environment and Natural Resources (DENR) warned of threats to 21 protected areas. At risk is the Verde Island Passage, a center of marine biodiversity, that links Mindoro to Batangas. “Nakaabot na kaninang umaga ang oil spill sa dalampasigan ng dalawang karatig bayan ng Pola at Pinamalayan (This morning the oil spill has reached the shores of nearby towns Pola and Pinamalayan),” Coast Guard Commodore Innocencio Rosario Jr., Southern Tagalog commander, told Rappler. “We presume it is industrial fuel oil with its appearance of black sticky and strong odor.” UPDATE: The @coastguardph has observed OIL SPILL STRANDING along the shoreline of Barangay Buhay na Tubig in Pola, Oriental Mindoro, today, 02 March 2023. pic.twitter.com/wcW7PEZ2ZN “Our troops from our (PCG) district stations here in Mindoro have documented the oil spill,” Rosario added. He said the BRP Melchora Aquino, a PCG Vessel, deployed it’s Rigid Hull, MTUG Titan, to start the mechanical recovery of spilt oil in the vicinity waters off the submerged motor tanker for further assessment. UPDATE: Kinumpirma ng @coastguardph na may halo na ring INDUSTRIAL FUEL OIL ang oil spill sa katubigan ng Naujan, Oriental Mindoro, ngayong araw, ika-02 ng Marso 2023. KARAGDAGANG DETALYE: https://t.co/XnYWKl8wUt#DOTrPH 🇵🇭#CoastGuardPH #MaritimeSectorWorks pic.twitter.com/AHgT7kPKF1 The PCG in Southern Tagalog has sent an augmentation request of forces from central headquarters, especially the Coast Guard Auxillary (Reserve). “I already sent a request letter to the national headquarters for some forces from Coast Guard Auxillary to augment our personnel on anticipation for extensive effect of oil spill on water of Mindoro,” said Rosario. He added that local government units in Oriental Mindoro had been informed of measures being taken to clean the spillage and the possible effects on the environment and livelihood. PCG’s Marine Environment Protection Unit, the DENR’s Environment Protection Management Bureau, and Malayan Towage and Salvage Corporation are coordinating to address the problem and consequences of the sea mishap. The oil from the submerged vessel has spread across a 40-kilometer radius, an area encroaching on 21 protected areas, including a fish sanctuary. Jay Lim of Tanggol Kalikasan, an environmental law group, also told Rappler the oil spill threatens all marine ecology, including coral reefs that serves fish sanctuaries. “Kami ay nangangamba sa masamang kontribusyon ng oil spill sa karagatan na nakakaambag para masira ang mga marine ecology particular ang coral reef na nagsislbing pangitlugan ng mga isda.” Lim said. (We fear that the oil spill is contributing to the damage to the marine ecology, particularly to the coral reefs that serve as fish spawing ground.) – Rappler.com

TV Patrol, Miyerkules, 9 Abril 2025 KUALA LUMPUR — President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. stood firm that filing cases against those involved in the flood control fiasco cannot be done in haste, stressing that due process should be observed. This was in response to some business and labor groups who criticized him over supposed “slow” actions vs corruption into the flood control scandal. He said that he constantly gets messages telling him to order people allegedly involved arrested. “‘Alam naman natin kung sino sila, ikulong mo na.’ ‘Kunin mo lahat ang pera nila.’ ‘Ipagbenta mo na ‘yung mga bahay nila, ibalik sa ano…” ('We know who they are, just jail them'. 'Take all their money'. 'Sell their houses...') What would then I be accused of if we did that?’ Marcos Jr. said in a press briefing following the closing ceremony of the 47th ASEAN Summit and Related Summits Tuesday, October 28. ADVERTISEMENT Business groups noted over the weekend that months since Marcos Jr. called out flood control anomalies in his State of the Nation Address, they were “told to be content with immigration lookout bulletins for now” instead of hold-departure orders that are issued by courts. The chief executive argued that cases should be backed up by solid evidence to assure conviction. He said that people who have stolen billions from the government may end up being set free if weak cases are filed against them. “That would be much worse result. So, due process must be observed,” Marcos Jr. asked. “We must make sure na alam – alam naman talaga natin kung sino sila. Kaya tiyakin natin na makukulong talaga sila at ang kanilang mga ninakaw ay ibalik sa gobyerno, ibalik sa tao,” he added. ADVERTISEMENT (We must make sure — we really do know who they are. So let us make sure that they are convicted and what they stole will be returned to the government, to the people) He said the government only gets “one chance at this" and that government cannot waste the opportunity to bring corrupt officials and contractors to account. “So, do you want to get it done quickly or do you want to get it done right? That's the choice that we have,” he added.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: 'Marahan, tahimik, hindi pinuwersa': DOJ says Duterte arrest followed due process | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: The Philippine government followed due process in serving the International Criminal Court warrant to former president Rodrigo Duterte upon his arrival at the Ninoy Aquino International Airport last Tuesday, a justice official said. This included the reading of his Miranda rights and explanation of why he has being arrested, Justice Undersecretary Nicholas Felix Ty said. “Ibinigay talaga ang lahat ng palugit kay President Duterte at sa kanyang mga kasamahan. Ginalang namin ang kanyang lahat ng Karapatan bilang dating pangulo. Sa dulo, tahimik at tinanggap ang kalagayan na dapat talagang maipatupad ang warrant of arrest at maisakay siya sa eroplano papunta sa The Hague,” he said in a TeleRadyo Serbisyo interview. “Hindi pinwersa, hindi namin kinalimutan na siya ang dating pangulo, may edad na. Sinigurado namin na tahimik at marahan ang proseso.” ADVERTISEMENT “Hindi defiant ang dating pangulo. May mga abogado siya na ipinaglaban nila ang posisyon nila. Marami silang hiniling pero si President Duterte tahimik lang siya, tanggap niya ang pangyayari.” He rejected Vice President Sara Duterte’s claim that the arrest was a form of “state kidnapping.” He added Duterte can seek legal remedy with the ICC in The Hague after the court took jurisdiction of the former president. The ICC, based in The Hague, has said that there were "reasonable grounds" to believe Duterte committed the crime against humanity of murder as an "indirect co-perpetrator" during the anti-drug campaign that rights groups estimate killed tens of thousands of people. ICC Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan said Duterte’s arrest is an important moment for alleged victims of his "war on drugs.”

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Mga anak ni Duterte iginigiit na 'dinukot' siya ng pamahalaan | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: Iginiit ng kampo ni dating Pangulong Rodrigo Duterte na dinukot umano siya ng gobyerno at ilegal na inilipad sa The Netherlands noong March 11. Naghain ng magkakahiwalay na traverse comments sa Korte Suprema ang tatlo sa mga anak ni Duterte kaugnay ng kanilang petisyon na maibalik sa Pilipinas ang kanilang ama. Nanindigan naman ang Malakanyang at Department of Justice na nakabatay sa batas ang pag-aresto sa dating pangulo. Nagpapatrol si Adrian Ayalin. TV Patrol, Martes, 25 Marso 2025 In a video posted Tuesday on his Facebook page, Barzaga accused the PCG of supposed "corruption" because it allegedly provided "high-ranking positions to undeserving public officials." He said the PCG was "escalating tensions" in the West Philippine Sea and called out its supposed interference with the China-Taiwan conflict. Barzaga claimed that there was "no future for the Philippines with the PCG holding power over our military" and said the agency "no longer serves the interest of the Filipino people." Tarriela, spokesperson for West Philippine Sea concerns, said Wednesday that Barzaga was seeking to "distort facts" and "disrespect the brave men and women of the PCG who risk their lives daily" defending the country's sovereignty. ADVERTISEMENT "As a member of @HouseofRepsPH, to call for the abolition of the PCG and dismiss our existence as a 'waste of government funds' is both reckless and deeply insulting to the 36,000 strong of the PCG who serve this nation with honor and courage," he said. "We urge the public to discern facts from fiction and to stand with those truly committed to the defense of our national interests," Tarriela said on X. He called Barzaga's World War 3 assertions "alarmist, inaccurate, and deeply irresponsible," noting that the West Philippine Sea issue was "not an abstract geopolitical issue—it is part of our national patrimony." "It encompasses vital fishing grounds, trade routes, and marine resources that sustain millions of Filipino families," he said. The PCG's presence in the West Philippine Sea, Tarriela said, "is not an act of provocation," explaining that its absence would mean "a blatant dereliction of duty." ADVERTISEMENT He said the PCG was mandated to uphold and protect the Philippines' sovereign rights under international law, including the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea and the 2016 arbitral ruling that rejected China's sweeping claims in the South China Sea. Tarriela rejected Barzaga's accusation that the PCG confers high positions on political figures, saying the honorary ranks are only symbolic and do not grant them authority. He said the politicians do not hold command positions and operational control over the PCG. The coast guard official noted that the PCG, while an armed and uniformed service, is not part of the Armed Forces of the Philippines but is an attached agency to the Department of Transportation. "To portray the PCG as a military is not only inaccurate—it undermines the principles upon which civilian maritime governance is built," he said. ADVERTISEMENT "Our men and women operate in the harshest conditions—rescuing those in distress at sea, enforcing maritime laws, protecting our environment, and standing firm against coercion in the WPS. Many have sacrificed their lives in the line of duty. To trivialize their service as wasteful betrays not only a lack of understanding but also a lack of empathy," Tarriela said.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Sara Duterte should face impeachment case like father faced ICC charges: lawmaker | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — Vice President Sara Duterte should face her impeachment case just as her father, former President Rodrigo Duterte, faced the charge against him before the International Criminal Court, according to a lawmaker. The Vice President went to the Netherlands after his father was arrested in Manila on Tuesday on an ICC warrant and was flown to The Hague. Vice President Duterte’s impeachment trial is seen to start on July 30 or more than four months from today. “Patungkol naman sa impeachment, medyo hindi pa naman ito nagsisimula, at naglabas din naman ng pahayag ang ating Pangalawang Pangulo na handa siyang harapin ang impeachment sa kanya. So, panghahawakan natin ‘yun, dahil naghahanap ang ating mga kababayan ng transparency at accountability,” House Assistant Majority Leader and Zambales 1st District Representative Jefferson Khonghun said. ADVERTISEMENT “So, dapat harapin ng ating pangalawang Pangulo ‘yung issue sa kanya na katulad ng pagharap ng kanyang ama sa mga issue sa ICC,” he added. House Deputy Minority Leader and ACT Teachers Party List Representative France Castro also hopes Vice President Duterte will appear in her impeachment trial. “Kay VP Sara Duterte… tama naman ang ginagawa mo na tulungan ang iyong tatay. Anyway, ‘yan talaga ang kultura natin bilang Pilipino. Pero as a government official, Vice President na mayroon ding kinakaharap na accountability sa ating mga mamayan, dapat harapin mo rin ‘yung impeachment complaint, at dumalo ka sa magiging impeachment trial in due time,” she said. House Assistant Majority Leader and Manila City 1st District Representative Ernesto Dionisio Jr., meanwhile, issued a reminder that the official online accounts of government agencies should not be used for personal matters. He issued the statement after the official Facebook page of the Office of the Vice President briefly changed its profile photo with one showing a ribbon with the message “Bring PRRD home”. “Minsan, lalo na ‘pag mainit ‘yung damdamin, we do things… abruptly. So, siguro that's one of the reasons why sa personal page niya, that's okay. Pero ‘pag doon sa pamahalaan, of course, kaya nga siguro tinanggal naman din nila agad. Of course, kapag government, official website, we should not use it on a personal capacity,” Dionisio said.

Mike Defensor that he is. The Marines are the Navy's infantry force and are under its command. In a statement, Capt. Marissa Martinez, Navy spokesperson, said Guteza retired from the corps in June 2020 and "no longer falls under the administrative authority of the Philippine Navy." She said that "any engagements or interactions he may have at present are undertaken in his personal capacity." ADVERTISEMENT Martinez stressed that Guteza is not under the protection of the Philippine Marine Corps and that the Navy has "no involvement in his personal affairs." She added the Navy is "a professional and non-partisan organization" that is focused on national defense. The Navy’s statement came after Defensor claimed that Guteza — recently identified as a “surprise whistleblower” in Senate investigations — was in the custody or protection of the Marines. Defensor, who gave no evidence of his claim, said Guteza had sought safety among “fellow ex-Marines” following the controversy surrounding his testimony. Guteza, a retired Marine and former security consultant, surfaced in September before the Senate Blue Ribbon Committee. ADVERTISEMENT In his affidavit and testimony, he alleged that he personally delivered cash-filled suitcases to the homes of then House Speaker Martin Romualdez and then Ako Bicol party-list Rep. Zaldy Co in connection with alleged irregularities in flood-control projects. Defensor said Guteza has declined to enter the government’s witness protection program. However, questions have since emerged over the authenticity of Guteza’s sworn affidavit. A Manila Regional Trial Court found that the lawyer whose signature appeared on the document denied notarizing it. Senate officials have said the issue of notarization could affect the affidavit’s validity but not necessarily invalidate Guteza’s oral testimony before the committee. ADVERTISEMENT As for reports of an alleged ambush involving Guteza, Captain Martinez said the Navy has no information about such an incident. She added that the matter should be referred to the Philippine National Police for proper investigation.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Paano nga ba nagsimula ang UP Oblation Run? | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MAYNILA — Matagal nang tradisyon ang taunang Oblation Run ng Alpha Phi Omega (APO) Fraternity sa University of the Philippines Diliman. Pero higit sa paghahatak ng interes sa mga estudyante at tagalabas ng UP dahil sa mga lalaking tumatakbo nang hubo’t hubad, giniit ng grupo na wala silang hangad na kabastusan dito. Naging paraan ito ng protesta ng APO at pagbibigay-kamalayan sa mga panlipunang isyu mula nang unang isagawa ang Oblation Run noong 1977. Ngayong 2025, ipinaglaban ng frat ang pagsulong ng malinis at tapat na halalan, sa temang ‘Boto Mo, Hindi Benta Mo’. ADVERTISEMENT Inaasahan ng APO na sa paraan ng Oblation Run, makikisama ang taumbayan sa pag-alam at pag-aksyon sa mga importanteng isyu ng bansa. MANILA— The Department of the Interior and Local Government (DILG) is urging all local government units (LGUs) across the country to conduct comprehensive infrastructure audits on both public and private buildings to help communities prepare for the threat of strong earthquakes. In a statement, the DILG said assessing the structural integrity of buildings is vital to ensure public safety and to lessen the risk of casualties and property damage during major seismic events. Aside from inspecting key public facilities such as hospitals, schools, government offices, and emergency response centers, the agency also wants privately owned structures to be covered by the audits. “With the increasing frequency and intensity of earthquakes, proactive preparedness is our best defense... Through harmonized audits, stronger partnerships, and evidence-based planning, we can build safer, more resilient communities across the country,” the DILG said. ADVERTISEMENT The DILG in 2024 partnered with various government agencies and professional groups, including the Association of Structural Engineers of the Philippines and the Philippine Institute of Civil Engineers, to develop the Harmonized Infrastructure Audit Tool (HIAT). The HIAT serves as a standardized framework for evaluating building resilience and identifying potential vulnerabilities before disasters strike. According to the DILG, 18 high-risk LGUs in Metro Manila, CALABARZON, and Central Luzon, areas traversed by the West Valley Fault, have already been trained to carry out infrastructure audits. Another 12 LGUs in the National Capital Region and 20 in Cavite, located outside the fault corridor, have also completed the training, while 10 more LGUs in Central Luzon are expected to follow suit by the end of the month. As part of the nationwide rollout, the department has also built a corps of trained coaches composed of technical experts from professional organizations, academic institutions, and local governments representing 74 LGUs nationwide. ADVERTISEMENT These coaches will mentor local audit teams and guide them in using the HIAT effectively. The DILG is also encouraging private sector participation through the establishment of Local Infrastructure Learning Hubs in its regional offices. These hubs will serve as centers of collaboration among LGUs, engineers, and schools to support audit teams led by local chief executives and composed of building officials and disaster management officers. “By institutionalizing innovative safety mechanisms and strengthening intersectoral collaboration, the DILG reaffirms its commitment to building disaster-ready localities and ensuring a safer infrastructure sector for all Filipinos.”

ABS-CBN.article_headline: PAOCC: P210M spent since 2023 for detained POGO workers, billions in assets seized | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The Presidential Anti-Organized Crime Commission (PAOCC) on Wednesday said it has spent about P210 million in the past two years for the detention of Philippine Offshore Gaming Operators (POGO) workers arrested since the crackdown began in 2023. The PAOCC spends about “P35 million every 4 months” for the food, water, electricity, security officials and administrative costs for POGO workers who are awaiting deportation, said spokesperson Winston Casio. “Roughly two years na po so we may have spent already...P210 million to end this problem,” he told Palace reporters. The Bureau of Immigration (BI) explained that the PAOCC had to shoulder some of its costs as their detention facility in Taguig could only house up to 100 foreign nationals for deportation. ADVERTISEMENT “Ang PAOCC napakalaki ng tulong (has been a great help) in terms of housing them prior to deportation,” BI spokesperson Dana Sandoval said. As of December 2024, the PAOCC has deported 2,121 foreign nationals working in illegal POGO hubs. Nearly 340 others are awaiting deportation, according to data from the agency. “This does not include those who voluntarily left the country,” Casio said. But, Casio said, PAOCC's expenses have to be seen in the context of property seized in its operations. “We could have already gained anywhere between P20 billion to P30 billion worth of real estate properties, tangible items, cars, name it,” he said. ADVERTISEMENT He said that Anti-Money Laundering Council has already ordered market valuation of seized items and properties. Among the seized properties from POGOs that are awaiting deposition are several high-value properties in Pasay City, a hotel in Cebu, mega compounds in Tarlac and Pampanga, as well as 134 seized vehicles, Casio said. Most of the POGO-linked foreign nationals who were either deported or awaiting deportation are from Vietnam, China, Indonesia and Myanmar, data from the BI showed. Immigration officials are also working with various embassies so that they could shoulder the repatriation flights of their respective nationals who were involved in illegal gambling operations here, the agency’s spokesperson said. Last year, President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. banned all POGOs in the Philippines after congressional investigations and multiple raids showed that the industry was linked to several criminal activities including torture, prostitution and human trafficking. ADVERTISEMENT Since the ban took effect on January 1, 2025, only 11,000 of the 33,000 registered POGO workers have remained in the Philippines, according to data from the BI. Of the 11,254 POGO workers who stayed in the Philippines, 121 have been deported, 518 have been arrested, while 45 other voluntarily surrendered.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Child rights group urges Marcos Jr. not to veto teen pregnancy prevention bill | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA -- A child rights group on Monday urged President Ferdinand Marcos, Jr. not to veto a bill meant to prevent teen pregnancies, saying he should read it carefully instead. This, after Marcos, Jr. slammed "woke absurdities" in the bill that supposedly seeks to teach children to masturbate and take away parents' authority over their offspring. But in a statement, Child Rights Network (CRN) Philippines – considered the largest alliance moving for child rights legislation in the country – said it was better if the President explained which parts of the bill were questionable to him. "Comprehensive Sexuality Education or CSE is just one of its components and is just a reiteration of what is already in the RH Law and the Executive Order signed by former President Duterte in response to NEDA’s declaration of teen pregnancy as a national social emergency," said CRN Philippines in a statement. ADVERTISEMENT "Kami ay umaasa na hindi niya ive-veto ang isang bill na naglalayong makapagtapos ng pag-aaral ang teen parents, matulungan sila at ang kanilang mga anak through health services, at mabigyan ng age-appropriate at culturally sensitive information ang mga bata at kabataan para mapigilan ang teen pregnancy," it added. For the group, what's important is that the President read the provisions in the bill thoroughly and carefully, as the proposed law underwent consultations with child rights organizations. "Wala po sa bill ang sinasabi n’yong dahilan kung bakit ito ive-veto. This bill has undergone consultations with child rights organizations responsible for advocating laws that protect the Filipino children," the group said. The Comprehensive Sexuality Education recently became a center of discussion after lawmakers expressed concern on its implementation by the Department of Education as early as Kindergarten, and the Senate Bill No. 1979 or the proposed Prevention of Adolescent Pregnancy Act. Sen. Risa Hontiveros, chair of one of the committees that prepared Senate Bill No. 1979, said that childhood masturbation was not part of the proposed legislation. Hontiveros earlier said critics of the bill were making false claims.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Marcos Jr.: Duterte 'lying' about alleged 'blank items' in 2025 spending bill | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: Former president Rodrigo Duterte branded a liar by President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. Duterte had echoed allegations that the president signed a 2025 budget law that is susceptible to abuse. -ANC, The World Tonight, January 20, 2025 GYEONGJU, South Korea — President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Friday joined other world leaders in the 32nd Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) Leaders’ Summit, where host country South Korea called for “harmony and coexistence” despite differences in national interests. South Korean President Lee Jae Myung in his opening remarks urged APEC members to “become connected and be more open” to one another so that the region — which registered 48 percent of global trade — “can go down the path of prosperity.” “Our reality does not leave much room for rosy forecasts. We are all at an infliction point of rapid changes in international order,” said Lee, whose country is hosting the annual regional meeting this year. “Free trade is facing wild changes. Uncertainties are growing for the global economy and trade and investment is losing its vitality,” he said during the APEC Economic Leaders’ Meeting Informal Dialogue with Guests. ADVERTISEMENT “Cooperation and solidarity is the only answer that will lead all of us to a better tomorrow. We cannot always be on the same page as each member economy may have their own interests, yet we cannot always unite with the ultimate goal of gathering strength for co-prosperity.” Lee’s opening statement comes as Manila and Beijing’s relations continue to be marred by China’s incursions in the Philippines’ exclusive economic zone despite a 2016 arbitral ruling that invalidated its sweeping 9-dash line claim in the South China Sea. This year’s APEC also marks the first time that Marcos Jr. and Xi would meet in person since January 2023, when the Filipino leader traveled to Beijing for a state visit in an attempt to amicably settle disputes in the strategic waterway where trillions-worth of goods pass through annually. The Summit is being held in Gyeongju — South Korea’s ancient capital — where consensus building has been honored for centuries, Lee said. “Our reality does not leave much room for rosy forecasts. We are all at an infliction point of rapid changes in international order,” Lee said, noting that “free trade is facing wild changes” while “uncertainties are growing for the global economy, and trade and investment is losing its vitality.” ADVERTISEMENT “[But] The Hwabaek spirit does not enforce any single idea but rather strive to achieve a harmony of different voices, exploring the path for harmony and coexistence,” he said. “The more we become connected and the more open we become to one another, the further we can go down the path of prosperity.” The Department of Foreign Affairs earlier said that Marcos Jr. is not expected to have a bilateral meeting with Xi on the sidelines of the APEC 2025, saying that this forum traditionally focuses on economic and trade issues, instead of security and defense. On October 30, Marcos Jr. told Filipinos here that he would focus on wooing investors from APEC economies to help boost the Philippines’ tech industry as the world further shifts to digitalization and artificial intelligence. Marcos Jr. has described the APEC as a “very important” meeting, underscoring that the regional bloc represents over 80 percent of the Philippines’ trade.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: House OKs on 2nd reading bill to expand gov’t assistance for private basic ed students | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The House of Representatives has approved on second reading a bill seeking to expand the coverage of the government assistance to students in private education, to include all the years of basic education, from kindergarten to senior high school. During the House plenary session on Monday, House Bill 11214 or the proposed Private Basic Education Voucher Assistance Act was approved via viva voce or voice voting. “Presently, government assistance and subsidies are not extended to elementary education, but are confined to students in Grades 7 through 12, at the secondary level, where the challenges related to poor learning outcomes remain a significant challenge. Expanding the program to cover these earlier educational stages would help address these concerns and ensure more comprehensive support for students in need,” House Committee on Basic Education and Culture Chairperson and Pasig City Representative Roman Romulo said. “The program has played a significant role in alleviating overcrowding in public high schools,” he added. ADVERTISEMENT Under the amended version of the bill, the voucher assistance will be provided to students from middle income families as determined by the Philippine Statistics Authority, who attended public schools identified by the Department of Education as congested or those living in areas with congested public schools, or without a nearby public school, who wish to enroll in private basic education schools. Students, who are most vulnerable and underprivileged, shall receive a higher voucher amount as determined by the Basic Education Assistance Council or BEAC. Citing data from the Department of Education, Romulo said 398,930 students transferred from private to public schools at the height of the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020. Between 2020 and 2022, enrollment in public schools increased by 1.5 million students, while in private schools, it dropped by almost a million students.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Ex-solon confident impeachment vs VP Sara Duterte will breeze through Congress | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA -- Former Bayan Muna Rep. Teddy Casiño said Wednesday it will be "easy" to get the required number of votes in the House of Representatives to advance the impeachment complaints filed against Vice President Sara Duterte. The impeachment complaint needs one-third of the Congress or 105 votes for it to be forwarded to the Senate. "Honestly, tingin ko madali 'yung 105... Ito'y dahil ilang buwan nang iniimbestigahan ng Kongreso ito e. Alam na alam na ng mga congressman 'yung mga pagkakamali at 'yung mga pagkukulang ng vice president," Casiño said in TeleRadyo Serbisyo's Johnson Ikwento Mo. "So tingin namin, madali sila makagagawa ng desisyon. Of course, ang challenge nito ay sa Senado. Ang importante naman nito sa Senado ay magkakaroon pa ng trial 'yan... so tayo ay umaasa na kung magiging objective lamang at tapat ang mga senador, makukumbinsi sila na dapat ma-impeach ang vice president," he added. ADVERTISEMENT The former lawmaker, who is also the current chairperson of Bagong Alyansang Makabayan (BAYAN), said that the issue should not be seen through the lens of the politicians' alliances and parties but by their obligations to the public. "Ano man ang kanilang partido o paniniwala, obligado ang mga congressman at senador na tingnan 'yung complaint, tingnan 'yung ebidensya, tingnan 'yung aming mga argumento na alam din ito ng buong publiko and, based on that, kailangan nilang magdesisyon batay sa kanilang konsensya at batay sa kanilang masusing pag-aaral ng ebidensiya," he said. When asked why they still filed an impeachment complaint despite President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s earlier discouragement on the matter, Casiño said it was a matter of holding the vice president accountable. "'Yan po ay opinion ni President Marcos. Ang usapin naman dito ay hindi 'yung opinyon ng presidente. Ang usapin dito ay nagkamali ba o gumawa ba ng mga maling bagay ang vice president at paano siya pananagutin sa mga ginawa niya," he said. "So for us it doesn't matter kung ang tingin ni President Marcos ay hindi dapat [mag-file.] Tingin namin, sa ilalim ng batas at Konstitusyon, may pananagutan ang vice president at kailangan niyang harapin ito," he continued. ADVERTISEMENT The vice president is already facing two impeachment complaints; the first was a civilian-drafted complaint filed last December 2, and the latest one was filed on December 4. The first impeachment complaint alleged Duterte committed "culpable violations of the Constitution, graft and corruption, bribery, betrayal of public trust, and other high crimes," all of which are grounds for impeachment. The second one, however, only revolves around how the vice president "betrayed the public's trust."

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Malaysian foreign minister plans to visit PH this year | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — Malaysia's foreign minister is set to have an official visit in the Philippines this year to mark the two nations' 60th anniversary of diplomatic relations. Malaysian Embassy in Manila’s Deputy Chief of Mission Mohd Fareed Zakaria said Thursday that he is happy to announce the coming visit of Malaysian Foreign Minister Dato’ Seri Utama Haji Mohamad Bin Haji Hasan in the country. “He will be coming here hopefully in the coming months, July, August. We’re planning his visit here. Hopefully when he comes here [so] we can have a big notable programs that will highlight what Malaysia and the Philippines have achieved in the last 60 years of our relations,” he said. Zakaria said this would be the “highlight” of the two nation’s enhanced cooperation. ADVERTISEMENT However, he said he could not tell what these specific “notable” programs are yet. “At this point of time I don’t have that information yet but I believe it will be far-reaching, wide-ranging subjects that both foreign ministers can discuss,” he said. Aside from the Malaysia Foreign Minister’s visit, there will be a series of events that will kickoff this year to show active relations between the two nations, one of which is the Malaysia International Halal Showcase (MIHAS) 2024 set to take place in September. Intan Zalani, MATRADE Trade Commissioner in Manila, said they are working with the Department of Trade and Industry (DTI) to have Filipinos in MIHAS 2024. “We have been informed that a big possibility of the Philippines coming for the MIHAS to be part of the event as exhibitors. We are also looking to recruit more buyers to come to MIHAS to source for not only products from Malaysia but also Halal products from all over the world as well,” she said. “And we think that is also a good avenue for the Philippine halal exporters to promote in Malaysia because it is the biggest halal showcase the world,” she said. Zakaria, meanwhile, thanked the Philippines, especially the DTI who has been actively promoting and supporting the Halal Industry.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Marcos receives UAE Foreign Minister in Malacanang | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA (UPDATED) -- The Philippines and the United Arab Emirates on Tuesday expressed interest to further strengthen bilateral cooperation during a visit by the UAE Minister of Foreign Affairs in Malacanang. President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. and First Lady Liza Araneta-Marcos received Sheikh Abdullah bin Zayed Al Nahyan, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the United Arab Emirates, who is currently in the Philippines for a short visit. During their meeting, Al Nahyan expressed the United Arab Emirates' gratitude to the Philippines for the contributions of the Filipinos in their country. According to a 2022 data of the Philippine Statistics Authority, the UAE is second only to Saudi Arabia as the leading destination of OFWs globally, and is currently home to 13.7 percent of the 1.96 million OFWs worldwide. "My President… regards his gratitude to you sir, to the Philippines for how you've always been welcoming UAE, supportive to the UAE, and most of all how the Filipino people who have considered UAE as a second home have shown throughout those years not only dedication but love, and to you and the First Lady I would like to express our gratitude and appreciation," Al Nahyan said. ADVERTISEMENT The Philippine President thanked the UAE for the assistance and kindness it has extended to the Philippines and the Filipinos. "And I hope that we are able to reciprocate somehow because we are very grateful for the assistance that you have done… especially to our Filipino nationals who are working in the Emirates... We extend that relationship further and make it deeper," he said. The Emirati official meanwhile said that while both countries have continued to grow over the years, there is still much to be done to improve it further, particularly on trade. "Our relationship is growing, but not enough. We could do much better. It could be much better because I think we have an interest to further enhance it. But also the Philippines has shown that it's been welcoming investors, we would like to do more trade, and to finalize and sit down with the Philippines," he said. Also included in the meeting with Al Nahyan was Kathryna Yu-Pimentel, who took her oath Tuesday morning as Philippine Special Envoy to the UAE. Pimentel is the wife of Senator Aquilino "Koko" Pimentel. ADVERTISEMENT "I am profoundly honored by the trust and confidence President Marcos has placed in me," said Pimentel. "My mission is to help in the strengthening of our investment and trade relationship with the UAE." Pimentel has been active in various international forums on investment and economic cooperation hosted by UAE, including the World Government Summit in February 2024, United Nations Climate Change Conference or COP 28 last December 2023, Dubai Airshow and Dubai Watch Week in November 2023, Dubai Expo, and Techspo Dubai. "With the upcoming 50th anniversary of our diplomatic ties this year, I hope to be able to contribute to the further strengthening of our relationship with the UAE as the President’s special envoy," Pimentel said.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: PhilHealth excess funds for 2021-2023 total nearly P90-B | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The Philippine Health Insurance Corporation had excess funds that totaled P89.9 billion from government allocations in the last three years, PhilHealth President and CEO Emmanuel Ledesma Jr. confirmed before the House Committee on Appropriations on Monday. Of this amount, P27.1 billion was from 2021, P24 billion from 2022, and P38.8 billion from 2023. Lawmakers called out the “inaccurate estimates” for additional funding needed by PhilHealth for the period, and urged the state health insurer to either increase benefits or lower premium contribution rates. “Masasabi natin na error ito sa computation. Kasi kung tama ang pag-compute ng gobyerno ay hindi tayo magkakaroon ng excess funds. Ibig sabihin kung tama ang pag anticipate ng gagastusin para sa ating indigent households, para sa seniors, para sa PWD, at kayang-kaya naman itong ma-estimate, ay magiging tama sana ang isisingil sa gobyerno taun-taon,” House Committee on Appropriations Vice Chairperson and Marikina 2nd District Representative Stella Quimbo said. ADVERTISEMENT “There were a lot of duplications and the senior citizens, who apparently were either paying for their own premium or were still working, or ‘yung sumakabilang buhay na. In other words, there was an estimated 7.7 million na hiningian ng pondo. But what was validated was more or less around 5 million,” Iloilo 1st District Representative and Former Health Secretary Janette Garin. “Under the law, may dalawang courses of action ang PhilHealth, the first is pwede kayo mag-expand ng benefits. The second is pwede kayo magbaba ng kinokolekta sa kanila,” Quimbo told PhilHealth. “We are aggressively enhancing our benefits packages,” PhilHealth President and CEO Emmanuel Ledesma Jr. assured congressmen. Lawmakers also questioned PhilHealth’s exorbitant package for COVID testing, which was at P8,150 in the early parts of 2020. Garin said it was higher than the P2,000 to P2,500 range set by the World Health Organization. Former Health Secretary Francisco Duque III explained that test kits were of limited supply and global demand was high during the initial stages of the COVID pandemic, but noted that PhilHealth’s COVID test package eventually went down as the supply of test kits stabilized. ADVERTISEMENT “The issue here is the price. PhilHealth was paying P8,150 per COVID testing at ‘yun ang naging benchmark, kaya lahat ng private laboratories including government labs ay tinaga ang mga pasyente,” Garin said. “During the initial stage of pandemic, where there was scarce supply of test kits, the testing cost was clearly very high, but as soon as time went by and supplies and prices started to stabilize, then DOH with PhilHealth started to make corresponding adjustments. So they started to reformulate the testing fees, so that pababa nang pababa,” Duque replied. “It was really difficult. Everybody was scrambling for supplies. The whole world suffered from global supply chain shortage. This affected even the formulation of testing fees. You would see the downward trajectory of the testing cost as soon as the supplies became available and prices became stabilized,” he added. The Philippines, at the height of the pandemic, also entered into loan agreements with foreign financial institutions for $2.21 billion, which had a commitment fee of P162 million. But the government later decided to cancel the agreement for loans amounting to $800 million.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: DepEd urged to fully implement revised K to 10 curriculum | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA -- The Department of Education (DepEd) should implement in full the revised curriculum for Kindergarten to Grade 10, Cong. Roman Romulo said Wednesday. This is to spare students from learning under the current system which was labelled by international assessments as "ineffective." The congressman from the lone district of Pasig City, who is also the chair of the House Committee on Basic Education and Culture, said that DepEd should stop doing pilot implementation and installment of the "MATATAG Curriculum." This adjusted K to 10 curriculum seeks to address issues in the current education system including the congestion of content. It was piloted on academic year 2023-2024 in hand picked schools and selected grade levels only. ADVERTISEMENT The formal implementation will be done in phases beginning school year 2024 to 2025 with grade levels participating in batches until school year 2027-2028. Kindergarten, Grades 1, 4 and 7 will be the first to implement the curriculum next school year to be followed by Grades 2, 5 and 8 on academic year 2025-2026. Grades 3, 6 and 9 will begin its shift only on school year 2026-2027 while Grade 10 will be the last to roll out the curriculum on school year 2027-2028 "Ang sinasabi ko sa DepEd, tama ang MATATAG curriculum pero sa totoo, tama na ang pilot ng pilot lang. You have to implement it," stressed Romulo. "Ang tanong ko, kung gradual po iyan, papaano ang mga estudyante natin na hindi kasama [sa bawat taon]? So ibig sabihin they will go through the same system kung saan ipinapakita na satin ng international assessments na hindi nga ito effective," he also said. ADVERTISEMENT Romulo called on DepEd to revise its manner of implementation of the curriculum. "Sana i-implement natin ito ng mas mabilis at i-implement natin na mas maayos," he said. DepEd, for its part, explained the need to implement the curriculum in phases. "The design of the new curriculum is progressive at every entry level per key stage (Grades 1, 4, 7) meaning may [there are] prerequisite skills/competencies at each entry level that need to be mastered before they progress to the next grade level," Assistant Secretary Francis Bringas told ABS-CBN News. The MATATAG curriculum was finalized after two years of review on learning competencies and subjects of students. ADVERTISEMENT While it was launched during the term of Vice President Sara Duterte, the review started during the time of her predecessor, former Secretary Leonor Briones, after learning the “alarming poor performance learners in national and international assessments."

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Parents-teachers group ready to donate electric fans to public schools | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The National Parents-Teachers Association Philippines (NPTA) on Tuesday expressed its willingness to help public schools by donating additional electric fans to help alleviate heat inside the classrooms. "With regard to electric fans, ang nagpo-provide talaga ay PTA [Parents-Teachers Association]. Ang PTA officers ang pino-project agad ay electric fans, ceiling fans, stand fan and wall fan," NPTA Executive Vice President Lito Senieto told ABS-CBN News. "Iyong mga PTA officer, upon the recommendation of the chair, pwede naman po uli magkaroon ng project na naman," he added. Senieto said some parents have already volunteered to donate individually to ensure the comfort of their children. ADVERTISEMENT "May mga parents din na iyong kanilang mga anak, nasa dulo, hindi na tinatamaan ng hangin ng electric fan. Iyon din po nagboboluntaryo rin na mag-donate ng electric fan. Ang PTA nagaayos din ng mga sirang electric fan," he said. The Department of Education (DepEd) earlier assured schools of funds that could be used to purchase additional equipment or appliances that can fight heat inside the classrooms. "Mayroon naman po tayong binababang mga MOOE [maintenance and other operating expenses] sa ating mga schools para siguraduhin na kung nasira man ang electric fan ay mapagawa nila. Ventilation sa ating schools ay something very important," DepEd Undersecretary Michael Poa told ABS-CBN News on Monday. On Tuesday, more schools declared suspension of face to face classes and have shifted to alternative delivery modes such as modular learning, and online classes. These are the schools and local government units that made announcements as of 3:00 p.m. of April 2, 2024, according to DepEd.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: 'Design first before budget': DepEd yet to present blueprint of 'climate-resilient' classrooms, says solon | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) wants a stricter limit on interest rates imposed by financing and lending companies. Under its draft memorandum circular, the SEC wants the maximum nominal interest rate fixed at 6 percent per month, or about 0.2 percent per day. The effective interest rate will be capped at 10 percent per month, or about 0.33 percent per day, including the nominal interest rate and all other applicable fees, like processing fees, service fees, notarial fees, handling fees, and verification fees. But this excludes penalties for late and non-payment of outstanding scheduled amounts due. ADVERTISEMENT Lending and financing companies may only charge penalties of up to 5 percent per month for late payment or non-payment on outstanding amounts due. Lending companies that break this rule will be fined P25,000 for the first offense, and P50,000 for the second offense. Financing companies, meanwhile, will be fined P50,000 for the first offense and P100,000 for the second offense. On the third offense, the SEC may impose a fine equivalent to at least twice the penalty for the second offense, but not more than P1 million. The company’s financing and lending activities may also be suspended for 60 days, and its secondary license may be revoked. ADVERTISEMENT If the offense is grave, the SEC may also suspend or revoke the company’s primary registration. The securities regulator is seeking public comments on the draft circular until November 14. SEC said it is doing this to strike a balance between consumer protection and the competitiveness of duly licensed lending and financing companies. “The number of borrowers struggling under excessive interest rates has continued to grow in recent years, as certain entities exploit the accessibility of online lending applications to trap our fellow kababayans in cycles of debt,” chairperson Francis Lim said. The SEC has been cracking down on online lending apps. ADVERTISEMENT In May, it revoked the corporate registration and financing license of Digido after it opened and operated four branches without obtaining a certificate of authority. In the same month, it issued a cease and desist order against the operator of MagicPeso over abusive collection practices. It also filed criminal complaints against the operator of online lending app Easypeso for abusive collection practices. Earlier in October, it issued a cease and desist order against the operator of online lending platforms Credit Cash and Credit Peso over unfair debt collection practices. The Presidential Anti-Organized Crime Commission has monitored some 300 online lending apps, many of which are bogus. Some bogus lenders even go so far as to issue rape or death threats to borrowers so they would pay up. Authorities, however, are facing a blank wall in going after abusive lending apps since the companies simply discard these preregistered SIM cards after promoting their services or threatening their borrowers.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Transpo chief assures no job losses as SMC takes over NAIA modernization | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA -- Personnel of the Manila International Airport Authority (MIAA) will still have their jobs once the government turns over the operations and maintenance of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport (NAIA), the Department of Transportation said. Transportation chief Jaime Bautista said this was agreed on by the department and San Miguel Corporation - SAP. READ: San Miguel consortium wins bid to rehabilitate NAIA "Part of the concession agreement is for the concessionaire to offer positions to existing employees of Manila International Airport Authority," Sec. Bautista said during the agency's 42nd anniversary on Friday. ADVERTISEMENT "Be it regular employees, contract of service or job order. Ibig sabihin, walang mawawalan ng trabaho dito," added Sec. Bautista. The San Miguel group earlier won the bidding for the rehabilitation project worth around P170 billion. MIAA employees earlier raised concerns over losing their jobs due to the rehabilitation projects. The group Samahang Manggagawa sa Paliparan ng Pilipinas earlier warned job loss during the project, adding that there was no guarantee they would be given the right benefits. DOTr also urged the consortium to give airport workers pay hikes and better terms as it takes over NAIA.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: NIA eyes building 50 dams by 2028 | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The National Irrigation Authority (NIA) on Tuesday said it hopes to complete at least 50 dams by 2028, underscoring President Ferdinand Marcos Jr.'s push to construct more dams during his administration. The NIA is pushing to build 10 dams this year, as well as 50 medium and 3 high dams by the end of Marcos Jr.’s term, said NIA administrator Eduardo Guillen. “Ang gusto ng ating pangulo ay mag shift tayo from flood control to water management,” he said in a press conference in Malacañang. “Kaya tayo nagkakaproblema ay yung mga malalaking dam na inaasahan natin ngayon… tinayo ito 50 years ago… Unfortunately, hindi na natin yan sinundan ng mga ganitong proyekto,” he said. ADVERTISEMENT “Ang gusto ng ating pangulo ngayon ay magtayo ng high dams,” he added, noting that these can also be used as in flood control, irrigation, hydro power, aquaculture, floating solar and tourism efforts. The NIA has crafted a design and build manual to quicken the construction of these dams, Guillen said. “Masho-shorten niya yung implementation ng dam from conception to actual construction by 3 years,” he said. Guillen also told reporters that despite the El Niño phenomenon, corn production increased by 5.9 percent, while rice production improved by 1.1 percent. So far, only 1 percent of farmlands were not irrigated, he said, saying these are the “tail-ends” of the irrigation lines. Last year, the Senate questioned the NIA’s failure to finish projects on time, including a dam in Tarlac that was supposed to provide irrigation for 34,000 hectares in 10 municipalities, to benefit 23,000 farmers. NIA told senators the project has been terminated with its former contractor.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: 9 Filipino crew members of seized tanker back in PH | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA (UPDATED) -- Nine Filipino crew members of an oil tanker seized by Iran's navy in the Gulf of Oman arrived in the Philippines on Sunday. Lord Rangasajo, one of the crew members who arrived, said they had positive interactions with the Iranians. "Maganda naman po ang pakikiharap ng mga Iranian sa amin. Wala naman po kaming naging problema," he said. He also mentioned that they were not harassed. ADVERTISEMENT "Mga eight commandos, they boarded us with the heavy guns but okay naman sila," he said. The Department of Foreign Affairs revealed that two more are expected to return this week. "'Yung dalawang aalis pa, Tuesday or Wednesday aalis sila," DFA Usec. Eduardo de Vega said. (Two more will depart on Tuesday or Wednesday.) The remaining six are awaiting replacements before returning to the Philippines. ADVERTISEMENT "Hindi naman sila hostage per se, kasi kusang loob silang naiwan doon dahil binigyan ng double salary kaya out of their own free will sila na naiwan doon," he said. (They are not hostages per se because they willingly stayed there due to the double salary offered, so they chose to remain voluntarily.) In an interview on Bagong Pilipinas Ngayon on Monday, De Vega said the crew are healthy and happy to be back in the country. The nine seafarers were able to return after they were replaced by Russian counterparts. “Ang kailangan na lang diyan mapalitan sila ng ibang crew men. Kasi ang sabi ng port authority sa Iran at saka ng manning agency, puwede namang umuwi kahit sino basta palitan sila kasi kailangan nagpapatakbo ng barko. Originally naisip nila Filipino rin ang kukunin eh hindi bakit kukuha eh di pareho din magkakaroon pa ng mga Filipinong ipit doon. Kaya ang sabi namin dapat ibang bansa,” De Vega explained. ADVERTISEMENT (What is needed is for them to be replaced by other crew men. The port authority in Iran and the manning agency said anyone can come home so long as they are replaced because a ship operator is needed. What they originally thought was to get other Filipinos but that would put them in a pickle as well. That’s why we said it should be another nationality.) “‘Yung sahod nila tuloy pa, binabayaran sila ng manning agency pero ang pagbayad dito sa pamilya dito sa Pilipinas. At ang sabi ng Department of Migrant Workers, ang nakikipag-ugnayan sa manning agency, pinaakyat pa nga ang suweldo,” De Vega said. (They continued to receive their salary, but this was paid to their family here in the Philippines. The Department of Migrant Workers who is coordinating with the manning agency, said the pay was actually increased.) The Overseas Workers Welfare Administration (OWWA) assured they are ready to provide psychocounseling to arriving seafarers, along with financial assistance accommodation, and air fare if they need to return to their provinces. "Kakausapin po muna natin sila kung magdecide sila na magse-settle sila rito sa Pilipinas then we will provide reintegration sa kanila," OWWA Deputy Administrator Atty. Honey Quiño said. ADVERTISEMENT (We will first discuss with them if they decide to settle in the Philippines, and then we will provide reintegration support.) The Filipino crew members were under Iran's custody following the Iranian Navy's seizure of the oil tanker St. Nikolas in the Gulf of Oman in January. Iran's action was a retaliatory response to the confiscation of Iranian crude oil from the same vessel by US forces in 2023. -- With a report from Victoria Tulad, ABS-CBN News.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: DRONE FOOTAGE: Pasig River esplanade | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: The first phase of the 25-kilometer Pasig River esplanade recently opened to the public, offering a brightly lit recreational space where people could take strolls. The development is open to the public from 6 p.m. to 10 p.m., authorities earlier said. The project will eventually include jogging paths, bike lanes and commercial areas with retail stores and cafes. Once the promenade is completed, it is expected to traverse 5 cities, giving the public a “major transportation lane that will cut across local governments of the National Capital Region,” said Undersecretary Avelino Tolentino III of the Department of Human Settlements and Urban Development (DSHUD). ADVERTISEMENT To aid in the clean-up of the Pasig River, the Metropolitan Manila Development Authority (MMDA) is also adding trash skimmers which prevent floating debris and garbage from flowing along the river. It has also started recycling water hyacinths and water lilies to make charcoals briquettes and lily pots. All plans to rehabilitate and develop the Pasig River to make it a tourist attraction is expected to be completed within the term of President Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the MMDA said. Last week, Marcos said the rehabilitation of the Pasig River would be a “people-centered, community-driven development” instead of a mere “cosmetic” project. Informal settlers who will be affected by the project will not be displaced, as housing units will be built within the city where these families reside, the MMDA had said. The DHSUD earlier said the P18 billion needed to establish the mixed-use riverside park would be sourced from the private sector. — With reports from Joyce Balancio and Katrina Domingo, ABS-CBN News
matched_phrases: department of human settlements and urban development

ABS-CBN.article_headline: DA chief names chief of staff, undersecretary for operations | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: The Department of Agriculture has formalized the appointment of additional key members of Agriculture Secretary Francisco Tiu Laurel, Jr’s staff. Atty. Alvin John F. Balagbag, a corporate lawyer who has served as general counsel of the Frabelle Group of Companies and corporate lawyer of PNOC-Renewables Corp., was appointed as Tiu Laurel’s Chief-of-Staff. Balagbag, who was also named as DA Undersecretary, earned his law degree from the University of Sto. Tomas and a Master’s Degree in Business Administration from the Ateneo Graduate School of Business. Meanwhile, Engr. Roger Navarro was designated as undersecretary for operations in concurrent capacity with his other designations. ADVERTISEMENT Although an engineer by training, Undersecretary Navarro has listed himself as farmer by occupation, working for Navarro Farms in Misamis Oriental. He graduated from the University of San Jose Recoletos in 1989 with a Bachelor of Science degree in Industrial Engineering. Tiu Laurel also signed the appointment of DA’s representatives to the technical working group drafting the implementing rules and regulations of The Internet Transactions Act of 2023. The new DA representatives included Director IV Honorio Flameno Ph. D. and Information Technology Officer III Xerxees Remorozo. New officers-in-charge include Director IV Atty. Roland Tulay for the Office of The Assistant Secretary for Administration and Office of the Undersecretary for Administration; Director III Eduardo Lapus for the Office of the Regional Executive Director for the field office in Region III; and Agriculture Center Chief II Mario Ruinata for the officer of the Regional Director at the Bureau of Fisheries and Aquatic Resources’ operations in Region VII in Cebu City. Director IV Atty. Christopher Banas was named as regional executive director of the DA’s field office in Region IV-B.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: 3 LTO employees arrested for stealing license plates | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: Three Land Transportation Office employees were arrested Thursday after they were caught stealing license plates from the agency’s plate making plant in Quezon City. LTO Chief Assistant Secretary Atty. Vigor D. Mendoza II identified the 3 as embossers Jenard Arida and Arjay Anasco; and warehouse staff Valeriano Nerizon, all assigned to the plate making plant at the LTO Central Office in Quezon City. Mendoza also ordered a manhunt against Allan Joker Abrigo, another LTO employee who served as team leader and possibly the boss of the three arrested suspects. "Gaya ng ipinangako natin sa taumbayan, we will not tolerate this kind of illegal activity and we will make sure that those who would dare to continue with their wrongdoings will be caught and held responsible. The arrest of these three people is proof of that," the LTO chief said. The investigation started after the LTO Intelligence and Investigation Division led by Renante G. Militante received information last year about possible theft of license plates. The investigation showed the three suspects were allegedly threatening their co-workers in the plate making plant if they would spill the beans on their modus. On Jan. 25, Militante was tipped that the three were again doing illegal activity, prompting him to contact Police Col. Bernard Yang, Senior Police Assistant to Interior and Local Government Secretary Benhur Abalos. A PNP operation led to the arrest of the three suspects while sneaking out five pieces of license plates out of the plant Thursday noon. “Based on the result of the investigation, they are selling the license plates at P10,000 per piece. We are now trying to determine how long and how many license plates have been stolen by these errant employees,” said Mendoza. "There is a syndicate behind these people involved in carnapping, smuggling and other serious crimes. We will run after the mastermind and the buyers. It appears na matagal na itong embedded at the LTO. More employees will be investigated as part of our weeding out of scalawags," he added. The suspects are now detained and are facing charges of Violation of Article 310 (Qualified Theft) and Article 294 (Robbery) of the Revised Penal Code. They will also face administrative charges. Technical Carnapping Based on the investigation, the 3 are being linked to a scheme involving newly-acquired motor vehicles through financing. The modus starts with a leader or a financier who will acquire a vehicle through financing and will illegally sell the vehicle using duplicated plates and fake OR/CR. The financier then procures the "fake" plates from his contact inside LTO at P20,000 per pair. ADVERTISEMENT

ABS-CBN.article_headline: DOH urges Pinoys to avoid using firecrackers to welcome 2024 | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: The DOH urges Filipinos to use harmless noise makers to welcome 2024. The appeal was made as fireworks-related injuries rise ahead of New Year's eve celebrations. — The World Tonight, ANC, December 26, 2023 MANILA - The Philippines held a Multilateral Maritime Cooperative Activity (MMCA) in the West Philippine Sea with its long-standing allies, the United States and Australia, and for the first time, New Zealand, on October 30-31, 2025. The two-day joint exercise marked the 12th iteration of the MMCA, a naval training activity designed to strengthen cooperation, enhance interoperability, and deepen defense ties among participating countries. Warships from the four nations sailed side by side in formation as part of the drills. The Philippine Navy’s BRP Jose Rizal (FF150), the US Navy’s guided-missile destroyer USS Fitzgerald (DDG-62), and New Zealand’s auxiliary ship HMNZS Aotearoa (A11) conducted replenishment-at-sea operations, which involved refueling and transferring supplies while underway—one of the most complex and critical naval operations. ADVERTISEMENT Naval personnel from New Zealand and Australia boarded the BRP Jose Rizal as part of the cross-deck training, while Filipino sailors also boarded their respective ships. The exercise focused on anti-submarine warfare and electronic warfare. “These are two capabilities that the AFP is currently improving and the training objectives were met,” said LtCdr. Michael Andres, Operations Officer of BRP Jose Rizal. “It is very important na lagi tayong nagti-training with other like-minded navies as we are promoting our regional peace and stability in the region,” Andres added. Phillip Penafiel, Leading Seaman Physical Training Instructor of the Royal Australian Navy, described the exercise as a memorable and meaningful experience. ADVERTISEMENT “It’s been an amazing experience. The hospitality is second to none… everyone is very welcoming,” he said. “I’ve been eight years in the navy and this is my first cross decking experience and to do it so close to home and people I’m familiar with is something I would never forget. It’s for the international engagements.” Naval helicopters from the Philippines, Australia, and New Zealand also joined the drills for the anti-submarine warfare exercise, demonstrating aerial coordination and maritime surveillance capabilities. However, five (5) Chinese warships or Peoples Liberation Army Navy vessels were detected nearby the activity area as the drills unfolded. “Dumikit lang siya sa atin, hindi naman talaga sila nakalapit. Ang pinaka-nearest nila ay 3-5 nautical miles sa atin, nevertheless, hindi ito nakaapekto sa activities natin,” LCdr. Andres said. “If ever na may ma-encounter kami na foreign intrusion, we always make sure na lagi namin silang nacha-challenge.” A Philippine Navy helicopter also successfully landed on an Australian warship as part of the cross-deck landing exercise. ADVERTISEMENT By Friday afternoon, sailors from all participating ships exchanged salutes and waves, marking the successful completion of the MMCA.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: Gatchalian urges Marcos Jr. to end POGOs | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: Senator Sherwin Gatchalian urged President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. on Friday to use his executive powers to shut down Philippine Offshore Gaming Operators (POGOs). “I am hoping that the President, through his executive power, already to start to whine down and eventually ban POGO. It’s causing us, not only social harm, but yung budget natin kinakain na rin,” Gatchalian said. The Philippine government has spent public funds to feed detained foreign POGO workers while processing their deportation proceedings and eventually, by loading them to the plane as deportees. “Imagine mo 200 ang dino-document nila, marami dun peke pa pangalan... tapos pagkain nila. Kasi kahit na dine-deport natin sila, we have to treat them like a human being and with dignity. Again, magastos yan and again wala namang naidudulot sa atin, bakit pa natin kailangang ipagpatuloy.” Gatchalian said. ADVERTISEMENT Gatchalian made a call while underlining his belief that unscrupulous POGO players and syndicates behind them continue to commit crimes in the country. “It’s not because tahimik ngayon ang POGO does not mean that there’s no crime happening,” said Gatchalian, chairman of the Senate Committee on Ways and Means. Gatchalian made the call a week after Congress marked the start of its Christmas break, leaving his POGO committee report’s recommendation to ban it in the Philippines, untouched. He also gave the President a copy of his report. While visiting Mindoro province, he said that Rep. Alfonso Umali told him that kidnapping activities in the province targeting Filipino-Chinese are becoming rampant. ADVERTISEMENT “He showed he showed me a video na mga local Chinese kinkidnap at tino-torture,” Gatchalian said. Aside from appealing to the President, Gatchalian vowed to talk to Senate President Juan Miguel Zubiri regarding the need to discuss his committee report on the floor. “We will continue to push. It’s already filed in the Senate. I just need to talk to the leadership on how to go about.. as long as POGO is allowed, we are allowing criminal syndicates to come in to our country,” the senator pointed out. “Magiging tahanan tayo ng mga criminal syndicates from China operating here,” he stressed. POGOs’ continued operations, coupled with the government’s plan to give Chinese tourists a “visa free” or “visa upon entry” arrangement are grave danger for the country, Gatchalian said. ADVERTISEMENT “Eh ngayon nga may POGO problem tayo nakakapasok sila ng madali, just imagine giving them visa free. It’s like a license for criminal syndicates to operate here in the Philippines. So, as long as POGO is here, it’s impossible to increase tourism coming from China because nahahaluan ng criminal syndicates coming to the Philippines,” he added.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: 5 days before deadline, gov’t firm: No extension for PUV consolidation | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The government remains firm in its stand not to extend the deadline for the consolidation of operators to comply with the jeepney modernization program. Transportation Undersecretary Timothy John Batan on Tuesday said there will be no more extension beyond the December 31 due date, despite appeals from drivers and operators to give them more time to comply with the policy. However, many jeepney drivers and operators remain hesitant to join a cooperative or corporation. Under a cooperative, an operator will lose ownership of his unit as this will now form part of the asset of the group that formed the juridical entity. A driver interviewed by ABS-CBN said his job as a driver is now hanging in the balance, 3 days before the last office day of the Land Transportation Franchising and Regulatory Board (LTFRB) for this year. Another driver and jeepney operator, meanwhile, said he is not willing to give up ownership of his unit which he bought for P90,000. HOPE AND APPEAL Transport group Piston remains hopeful that a temporary restraining order [TRO] will be issued by the Supreme Court after it brought the issue to the highest court. Manibela, on the other hand, appealed for compassion from President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. for the plight of drivers and operators who will lose their livelihood once the LTFRB suspends their operation come January 2024. Manibela said there are still around 40,000 traditional jeepney units that have yet to join the consolidation. When asked about the veracity of the figure, the Department of Transportation said they cannot yet dispute it, pending the LTFRB updating its record. But the DOTr said the LTFRB will issue special permits to plug the expected shortage of jeepneys in several routes in Metro Manila. Dispatching buses will be an option to ferry more passengers who are going to be affected by the shortage of traditional jeepneys, in case the impasse between Manibela/Piston and LTFRB is not resolved, the transport department said.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: DOTR says 8 groups eyeing NAIA rehab project | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA -- Transportation Secretary Jaime Bautista said he does not expect more groups to join the bidding for the rehabilitation of the Ninoy Aquino International Airport, even if the deadline is still more than a month away. Currently, there are 8 groups who showed interest and have bought bid documents. Bautista said though the December 27 deadline is still over a month away, that might be a short time if a new group wants to join the bidding for the rehabilitation, operation and expansion of NAIA. “It will take time for them to do the due diligence to study. It will take longer time to prepare the proposal,” said Bautista. He added that he met one-on-one some of the groups and so far, their plans and proposals appear to be viable. The eight prospective bidders who bought bid documents are: GMR Airports International B.V., San Miguel Holdings Corp., Manila International Airport Consortium, Spark 888 Management, Inc, Asian Airport Consortium, Cengiz Insaat Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S., Incheon International Airport Corporation, and Limak Insaat Sanayi ve Ticaret A.S. Bautista also commented on the statement of Cavite Governor Jonvic Remulla on co-branding Sangley airport with NAIA. Bautista said it needs to be studied by experts since it’s a new concept. “Kailangan review-hin technically, kung possible although yung runway niya [Sangley], yung orientation ay halos pareho [sa NAIA]," he said. The winning bidder of the P170 billion project is expected to be announced in the first quarter of next year. The winning bidder will be given 15 years to rehabilitate the airport’s passenger terminals and airside facilities. The deal may be extended for another 10 years if NAIA improvement targets are met.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: De Lima bail proves PH judiciary's 'independence': Imee | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA — The grant of bail to former Sen. Leila de Lima after nearly 7 years of detention is a "testament" to the Philippine judiciary's "independence," according to Sen. Imee Marcos. Muntinlupa RTC Branch 206 Judge Gener Gito allowed De Lima to post bail in the last drug case against her. It was a reversal of a denial by another judge in June of her petition for bail. "The independence of the judiciary is present and true. Our court is a court of law and justice, oblivious of personalities or any political noise. Sen. De Lima’s bail yesterday was a testament to that," the senator said. Making a similar comment on Monday, Justice Secretary Jesus Crispin Remulla said the grant of bail showed that courts are independent and "that democracy is alive and well in our country." ADVERTISEMENT De Lima had long insisted the charges were fabricated in retaliation for her investigation into then-President Rodrigo Duterte' war on drugs, which is now subject of an investigation at the International Criminal Court (ICC). Asked on ANC's "Headstart" whether bail would have been imaginable while Duterte was president, De Lima lawyer Bonifacio Tacardon said, "Based on our experience in Criminal Case No. [17-165], I think my answer to that question will be in the negative." He said that bail in that case was denied "despite our confidence that evidence against our client was not strong." Tacardon added De Lima's legal team "really felt pressure from all over with respect to that criminal case." De Lima was acquitted in Criminal Case No. 17-165 in May. ADVERTISEMENT In a separate interview on TeleRadyo Serbisyo, Dino De Leon — De Lima's spokesperson and a member of her legal team — said the former senator was "politically attacked every step of the way, her reputation was destroyed by an organized machinery of the state." De Lima, who is facing the last of three drug cases filed against her during the Duterte administration, was accused of taking money from inmates inside the Bilibid. Several witnesses died or recanted their testimonies, resulting in the dismissal of two of the three charges against de Lima. She still faces life in prison if convicted on the remaining charge. Sen. Marcos said the grant of bail showed there was no need for the ICC to get involved in drug war cases. "[ICC] has no business meddling with our justice system," Sen. Marcos said. ADVERTISEMENT The International Criminal Court is meant to be a court of last resort, for when national authorities are unable or unwilling to investigate and prosecute cases like the alleged crimes against humanity in the war on drugs. Human rights groups and advocates for drug war victims say domestic processes have failed to provide accountability and justice in the deaths. The ICC in July ruled that it would proceed with its investigation on the killings during Duterte's drug war, denying the Philippine government's appeal on the contrary.

ABS-CBN.article_headline: House panel approves substitute bill seeking to establish ICT hubs nationwide | ABS-CBN News
ABS-CBN.article_body: MANILA - The House Committee on Information and Communications Technology approved on Tuesday the substitute bill seeking to establish ICT hubs nationwide. The proposed measure mandates the Department of Information and Communications Technology to prepare a National ICT Plan, which will assess the needs of every province and identify the number of hubs to be developed there. Under the bill, every province shall have at least one ICT hub based on the type of activity it hosts -- from data farms to IT and business processing management, cyberskills learning hub and digital transformation center, and digital innovation hub, among others. “ICT hubs shall be developed in geographically equitable locations throughout the province,” the bill stated. ADVERTISEMENT “Any registered business enterprise in the ICT hub may be granted incentives, according to the performance-based, targeted, time-bound and transparent incentives program under… the CREATE law,” it added. “All ICT hubs established under this Act are hereby declared free zones within which any PTE may operate,” the bill noted. The measure further proposes that a digital network infrastructure be established to connect the local ICT hubs to the National Broadband Program though a core backbone network of the DICT, to be funded from the spectrum users’ fees.
